bibl.title: Despatch from H.C. Gaulk to James D. Porter, December 1, 1886
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

correspDesc.correspAction: Porter, James D. Acting Secretary of State Washington, D.C. <date when="1887-01-24"

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
<pb facs="20170615_145726"
Hon. Jas. I. Porter Acting Secretary Washington U.S.A
Sir,
Your two despatcched of the 2nd of Oct. last have been received
The two despatches referred to on First, the official notice of the acceptance of the resignation of Graham C. Campbell.
Second the offcial notice that I have been appointed "Acting Commercial Agent" of Gaboon.
Enclosed with these two despatches was a "form of official bound" to be expected by myself and returned to the Department.
Permit me, one reply to say that I respectfully decline to execute the Bond-- and for the following reasons. Necessarily a great length of time must elapse before my letter could reach you.
<pb facs="20170615_145742"
And a longer time before I could *unclear* the segnatums of Boudsmen in America.
And in addition to that the time necessar for you to obtain the recognition of the French Government, and afterwards revisit to me the Certificate of Assortment.
Already more than three months have passed since the official notice was given from this office by Graham C. Campbell that he would leave.
This is, of course. due suly to the length of time necessary for the exchange of letters.
Perhaps, for the present I may not remain here longer than three or four months.
And it will be will sight impossible for me to receive the Certificate before the expiration of that time.
I shall continue to earn for the office--the permittion and
<pb facs="20170615_145750" the books-until I find it necessary to return to America.
Then I will learn the can of these things to the member of this Mission who will succed we at this station.
I am not aware that I who have been "Acting" Com. Agnt. only have any authority were to name a successor.
Allow me to suggest thatI and others of our Mission think it would be will for the government of the U.S.to enquire into the trade of this part of the Coast.
One English prime, and one Ferman prime, do aninexcuse trade ben- besides swaller primes. But still then is a demand for some American productions *unclear* the demand than is for either English or German the lighter and better. American edge tools and axes. shovels,
<pb facs="20170615_145810"
plows. chiscles, the plain substatial American furniture, and American pine lumber for building purposes.
Only one American sailing vessel calls regularly at this port, and that about twice a year.
Our profession forbids ud giving as much time to the collection of statistics in regard to trade- imports/ exports as should be douer by the one holding this office.
I trust that I way to able to gather a fine statistics concerning trade on this part of the Coast.
For the present.
I remain Yours respectfully, H.C.Gaulk
